did.unittitle: Reverend James M. Lawson, Jr. Papers

chronitem.event: Born in Uniontown, PA in
Graduated from Washington High School in Massillon, OH in
Received his local preacher’s license in
Entered Baldwin-Wallace College in Berea, OH on
Became involved in the Fellowship for Reconciliation (FOR), which advocated nonviolent resistance to racism in

Declared a conscientious objector, refusing to take either a student or ministerial deferment, and served 14 months in federal prison (two months before graduating from college) for failing to report for the draft during the Korean War
Attended the Hartford Theological Seminary in CT in
Graduated from Baldwin-Wallace College with a BA in Sociology in
Worked as a Methodist minister and teacher at Hislop College in Nagpur, India where he studied the principles of nonviolence resistance that Mahatma Gandhi and his followers had developed
Attended Oberlin School of Theology in OH in
Attended Vanderbilt Divinity School in TN in
Served as president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference for 14 years, the organization founded by Martin Luther King, Jr. to end racial segregation by nonviolent protest
Organized sit-ins to stop segregation at lunch counters in downtown Nashville, TN

Expelled from Vanderbilt Divinity School on March 3, 1960, resulting in resignations of faculty members in protest and embroiled the campus and the Nashville community in a nationally reported controversy for months in the spring of 1960. A compromise was forged to stop most of the resignations and allow Lawson to complete dis degree in Nashville. Lawson instead chose to transfer to Boston University.
Founded, along with Martin Luther King, Jr., the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in
Completed his Bachelor of Divinity degree at Boston University ca.
Pastor at Scott Chapel Methodist Church in Shelbyville, TN from
Coordinated the Freedom Rides in
Pastor at Centenary United Methodist Church in Memphis, TN from
Member of an international peace team in Southeast Asia, replacing Martin Luther King, in
Coordinator of the James Meredith March in Mississippi in
First president of Black Methodists for Church Renewal in
Unsuccessful Campaign for Memphis Board of Education in
Chair of the Strategy Committee for the Memphis Sanitation Strike ca.
Martin Luther King, Jr., assassinated in Memphis, TN on
Returned to Vanderbilt on a sabbatical at the Divinity School in
Pastor at Holman United Methodist Church in Los Angeles, CA from
Arrested for praying on the White House grounds in
Chaired Peace Sunday in Los Angeles, CA in 1982, filling the Rose Bowl with 100,000 people
Hosted a weekly call-in show, ‘Lawson Live,’ where he discussed social and human rights issues affecting minority communities ca.
Retired at pastor at Holman United Methodist Church in
Named Vanderbilt’s Distinguished Alumnus in
Lawson’s expulsion from Vanderbilt in 1960 became a source of deep embarrassment to the university. During the 2006 graduation ceremony the university apologized for its treatment of Lawson.
Lawson became a Distinguished University Professor at Vanderbilt for the academic year

scopecontent.p: The papers contain a wide range of materials documenting Reverend Lawson’s life.
The papers are arranged and described in the following series:
